content.text: The student measures the distance \(d\) between the bottom of the clamp and the floor
This distance \(d\) remains constant throughout the experiment
He adjusts the length \(l\) of the pendulum to \(70.0 \text{cm}\)
Calculate the distance \(x\) between the centre of the pendulum bob and the floor. Record the value of \(x\) in the first row of Table 1.1.
Calculate, and record in the first row of Table 1.1, the period \(T\) of the pendulum. The period is the time for one complete oscillation.
Calculate, and record in the first row of Table 1.1, \(T^2\)
Complete the column headings in Table 1.1
The student displaces the bob slightly and releases it so that it swings. Fig. 1.2 shows one complete oscillation of the pendulum
He measures, and records in the first row of Table 1.1, the time \(t\) for 10 complete oscillations
He repeats the procedure using \(x = 45.0 \text{cm}, 40.0 \text{cm}, 35.0 \text{cm}\) and \(30.0 \text{cm}\)
He records the readings in Table 1.1
Plot a graph of \(T^2\) (y-axis) against \(x\) (x-axis). You do **not** need to start your axes at the origin (0,0)
State whether the graph line shows that \(T^2\) is proportional to \(x\). Give a reason for your answer
statement
reason
Explain why timing 10 oscillations gives a more accurate result for the period \(T\) than timing one oscillation
A student investigates the period of a pendulum. Fig. 1.1 and Fig. 1.2 show the arrangement
Write down the readings. Include the units for potential difference, current or resistance where appropriate in all parts of the question
Calculate the resistance \(R_{1}\) of the resistor using the equation \(R_{1} = \frac{V_{1}}{I_{1}}\)
She records the potential difference (p.d.) \(V_{1}\) across the resistor and the current \(I_{1}\) in the circuit
The meters are shown in Fig. 2.2 and Fig. 2.3

She connects a second resistor in series with the first resistor. She connects the voltmeter across both resistors and records the potential difference \(V_{2}\) across both resistors and the current \(I_{2}\) in the circuit
Calculate the resistance \(R_{\mathrm{S}}\) of the resistors in series using the equation \(R_{\mathrm{S}} = \frac{V_{2}}{I_{2}}\)

She connects the second resistor in parallel with the first resistor. She connects the voltmeter across both resistors. She records the potential difference \(V_{3}\) across the resistors and the current \(I_{3}\) in the circuit

Calculate the resistance \(R_{\mathrm{p}}\) of the resistors in parallel using the equation \(R_{\mathrm{p}} = \frac{V_{3}}{I_{3}}\) . Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment
Complete the circuit diagram to show the circuit she uses in part (c)
Describe how to extend part (c) of this experiment to investigate the relationship between the combined resistance of identical resistors connected in parallel and the number of resistors
In this type of electrical experiment, a variable resistor can be used to vary the current
Draw the circuit symbol for a variable resistor
A student investigates resistance
Fig. 2.1 shows the circuit she uses
• Draw a normal at the centre of side \(\mathbf{AB}\). Continue the normal so that it reaches the bottom of the ray-trace sheet. Label the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\)
• Label the point \(\mathbf{Q}\) where \(\mathbf{NL}\) crosses \(\mathbf{AB}\)
Draw a line EF parallel to CD and 2.0 cm below CD
Label the point J where NL crosses EF
Draw a line GH parallel to CD and 7.0 cm below CD
Label the point K where NL crosses GH
Draw a line PQ at an angle \(i = 30^{\circ}\) to the normal and on the left-hand side of the normal above the block

The student places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on line \(\mathbf{PQ}\). Fig. 3.1 is not drawn full size. Suggest a suitable distance apart for pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) in this type of experiment
distance apart    .........
On Fig. 3.1, measure the length \(a\) of the line from \(\mathbf{J}\) to \(\mathsf{P}_3\)
On Fig. 3.1, measure the length \(b\) of the line from \(\mathbf{K}\) to \(\mathsf{P}_4\)
Calculate \(\frac{b}{a}\)

The student observes the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through side CD of the block. She adjusts her line of sight until the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) appear one behind the other

She places a pin \(\mathsf{P}_3\) on line EF and a pin \(\mathsf{P}_4\) on line GH so that \(\mathsf{P}_3\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) seen through the block, appear behind pin \(\mathsf{P}_4\)
State one precaution that you would take in this type of experiment in order to produce an accurate ray trace
A student plans to test the suggestion that, in this experiment, \(\frac{b}{a}\) is a constant for all possible values of \(i\). List suitable values of \(i\) that the student could use
A student investigates the refraction of light through a transparent block
Fig. 3.1 shows the transparent block **ABCD** on the student's ray-trace sheet
A student investigates the rate of cooling, in air, of heated blocks made of different metals. The temperature of each block is increased by placing it in hot water
Plan an experiment to investigate how the rate of cooling depends on the metal from which each block is made
The following apparatus is available to the student:
cylindrical blocks of different metals, each with a hole for a thermometer, as shown in Fig. 4.1 a thermometer
Other apparatus normally available in a school laboratory can also be used
In your plan, you should:
· list any additional apparatus required
· explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation, including the measurements you would take
· state the key variables to be kept constant
· draw a suitable table, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)
· explain how you would use the results to reach a conclusion
